case_name: State v. Manshankar Prabhasbankar Dwivedi and Vallabhdas Gordhandas Thakkar

facts.text: Appeals Cr. A. No. 190 and 191 of 1969, and 63 and 64 of 1972 filed by certificate and special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Cr. A. No. 190 and 191 of 1969, and 63 and 64 of 1972. Appeals by certificate special leave

facts.text: Judgment and Order dated September 9, 1968 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 486 and 555 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated September 9, 1968 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 486 and 555 of 1966.

facts.text: Manshankar Prabhasbankar Dwivedi was a Senior Lecturer at the D.K.V. Arts Science College, Jamnagar which is a Government college.

anchor.surface_text: Manshankar Prabhasbankar Dwivedi was at the material time a Senior Lecturer at the D.K.V. Arts Science College, Jamnagar which is a Government companylege.

facts.text: Vallabhdas Gordhandas Thakkar was a legal practitioner conducting cases before the Income tax and Sales tax Departments and resident of Jamnagar.

anchor.surface_text: Vallabhdas Gordhandas Thakkar was a legal practitioner companyducting cases before the Income tax and Sales tax Departments. He was also a resident of Jamnagar.

facts.text: In April 1964 the Physics practical examination for the first year B.Sc. was to be held by the Gujarat University at Surendranagar centre.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that in April 1964 the Physics practical examination for the first year B.Sc. was to be held by the Gujarat University. One of the centres was Surendranagar.

facts.text: Dwivedi appointed as an Examiner for Physics practical.

anchor.surface_text: Dwivedi had been appointed as an Examiner for Physics practical.

facts.text: Dwivedi accepted gratification of Rs. 500/- other than legal remuneration for showing favour to candidate Jayendra Jayantilal Shah by giving more marks.

anchor.surface_text: He, is alleged to have accepted gratification of Rs. 500/- other than legal remuneration for showing favour to a candidate Jayendra Jayantilal Shah by giving him more marks than he deserved

facts.text: Dwivedi obtained Rs.500 through Thakkar.

anchor.surface_text: in the Physics practical examination. It is stated that he had obtained that amount through Thakkar.

facts.text: Dwivedi charged under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) read with s.5(1)(d) of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Dwivedi was charged with companymission of offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and s. 5  2  read with S. 5  1    d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947

facts.text: Thakkar charged under s.165-A IPC and s.5(2) of the Act read with s.114 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Thakkar was charged under s. 165-A, Indian Penal Code, and s. 5  2  of the Act read with s. 114 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Special Judge found both guilty and imposed 2 years rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs.1000/-, in default 6 months RI.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge who, tried both these persons found them guilty of the offence with which they were charged. He imposed a sentence of 2 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000/-

facts.text: Both convicted persons appealed to Gujarat High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyvicted persons filed appeals to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court found prosecution case proved on merits but acquitted on interpretation of sections.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the prosecution case had been proved against both Dwivedi and Thakkar on the merits but on the view which the High Court expressed about the ambit and scope of the sections under which the charges were laid they were acquitted

facts.text: Present appeals filed by the State against both respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeals have been filed by the State against both these persons who are respondents before us.

facts.text: Pranlal Mohanlal, complainant and brother-in-law of Jayendra, went to college with panch witness Shivaji.

anchor.surface_text: According, to the prearranged plan it was alleged that Pranlal Mohanlal who was the companyplainant and who was the brother-in-law of the student, Jayendra, went to the companylege

facts.text: Thakkar in porch of college demanded money for Dwivedi; Pranlal insisted pay after work done.

anchor.surface_text: , where the examination was to take place, along with a panch witness Shivaji. Thakkar was in the porch of the companylege and he demanded the money for being given to Dwivedi

facts.text: At Trolley Station, Thakkar took them to Vikram Lodge, demanded money again.

anchor.surface_text: When Pranlal and Shivlal reached the Trolly Station Thakkar came there and asked them to go with him to a place called Vikram Lodge which they did. There Thakkar again demanded money

facts.text: At about 11 A.M., three persons back to college first floor outside exam hall.

anchor.surface_text: At about 11 A.M. these three persons came back to the companylege and Went to the first floor where  3-L128SupCI/72 the examination hall was situate and stood outside the hall.

facts.text: Thakkar brought Dwivedi; Dwivedi said pay the amount to Thakkar.

anchor.surface_text: There Thakkar brought Dwivedi and Dwivedi said why are, you delaying. You are a fool you will spoil the life of the student. Pay the amount to Thakkar.

facts.text: Pranlal paid Rs.500 to Thakkar in presence of Dwivedi; Thakkar counted and pocketed it.

anchor.surface_text: Then Pranlal paid Rs. 500/- lo Thakkar in the presence of Dwivedi. Thakkar companynted the money and put it in his pocket.

facts.text: Dwivedi went back to his room; signal given, raiding party arrived, recoveries made, panchnamas prepared.

anchor.surface_text: Dwivedi went back to his room. Thereafter the signal was given and the raiding party arrived and made the recoveries. Necessary panchnamas were prepared.

facts.text: High Court agreed with Special Judge that prosecution case of demand and acceptance of Rs.500 for more marks to Jayendra proved.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the Special Judge that the prosecution case against the present respondents in respect of the demand and acceptance of bribe of Rs. 500/- for the purpose of giving more marks to Jayendra had been proved.

facts.text: Certificates for Cr. As. 190 and 191 of 1969 defective, not entertained; special leave granted for Cr. As. 63 and 64 of 1972.

issues.text: The first question which has to be resolved is whether respondent Dwivedi was a public servant within the meaning of the Ninth clause of s. 21, Indian Penal Code, keeping in view the capacity in which and the nature of the duties which he was performing as an Examiner of University which, it has been found, had no connection with his being a Government servant.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which has to be resolved is whether respondent Dwivedi was a public servant within the meaning of the Ninth clause of s. 21, Indian Penal Code, keeping in view the capacity in which and the nature of the duties which he was Performing as an Examiner of University which, it has been found, had numberconnection with his being a Government servant.

holdings.text: A University Examiner cannot be held to be an officer and therefore cannot be covered by the Ninth Clause of section 21 of the Penal Code when acting in that capacity without connection to his government servant position.

anchor.surface_text: We concur with the High Court that a University Examiner cannot be held to he an officer. Once that conclusion is reached, he cannot be covered by the Ninth Clause of section 21 of the Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No infirmity in High Court's reasoning; requires holding an office with government connection; supported by Ram Krishna Dalmia precedent; Gujarat University Act allows non-office holders as examiners; benefit of doubt in penal statutes.

holdings.text: Dwivedi was not guilty of an offence under s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act as there was no abuse of his position as a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: The next point which calls for decision is whether appellant Dwivedi was guilty of an offence under s.5 1 d of the, Corruption Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Abuse of position as public servant is essential ingredient; analysis of clause structure links abuse to corrupt/illegal means or otherwise; consistent with precedents like Narayanan Nambiar and Ram Krishna v State of Delhi; Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena does not decide otherwise.

holdings.text: Section 5(1)(d) of the Corruption Act does not apply to a public servant committing the act in a different non-public servant capacity without abusing public servant position.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act attributed to examiner capacity, not lecturer; no prosecution case of abusing lecturer position; essential that abuse be as public servant.

holdings.text: Thakkar cannot be held guilty of the offences under s.165A IPC and s.5(2) PCA r/w s.114 IPC if Dwivedi is not guilty.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Offences require principal (Dwivedi) to be guilty as public servant; abetment tied to non-existent offence.

precedents.citation: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Delhi Administration 1

anchor.surface_text: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Delhi Administration 1 . There, a Chartered Accountant had been appointed as an Investigator by the Central Government under the Insurance Act 1938 to investigate into certain matters and he was to get remuneration for the work entrusted to him.

precedents.case_name: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Delhi Administration
precedents.cited_proposition: A Chartered Accountant appointed as Investigator by Government does not hold an office and thus not a public servant under the latter part of Ninth Clause of s. 21 IPC even if remunerated by Government for public duty
precedents.cited_holding: he did number become an officer as he did number hold any office. The companyld number, therefore, become a public servant within the latter part of Ninth Clause of s. 21 of the Indian Penal Code

precedents.citation: Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena v. Delhi Administration 1

anchor.surface_text: Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena v. Delhi Administration 1 , overruling an earlier decision that in order to companystitute an offence under clause d of s.5 1 of the Corruption Act it is number necessary that the public servant while misconducting himself should have done so in the discharge of his duty.

precedents.case_name: Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena v. Delhi Administration
precedents.cited_proposition: To constitute offence under clause (d) of s.5(1) of Corruption Act, not necessary that public servant misconduct in discharge of his duty

precedents.citation: Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena v. Delhi Administration 1

anchor.surface_text: In Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena v. Delhi Administration 1 Saxena, who was an Upper Division Clerk, was approached by one Ram Narain, a fireman serving in the Delhi Fire Brigade, for assistance in obtaining a license for a double barreled shot gun which was, in fact obtained.

precedents.case_name: Dhaneshwar Narain Saxena v. Delhi Administration
precedents.cited_proposition: Public servant can commit offence under s.5(1)(d) even without acting in discharge of own duty, e.g., by corruptly influencing another public servant
precedents.cited_holding: it was number necessary to companystitute the offence under clause d of s. 5 1 that the public servant must do some thing in companynection with his own duty and there by obtain any valuable thing or pecuniary advantage

precedents.citation: State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal 2

anchor.surface_text: Overruling the earlier decision of this Court in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal 2 it was held that it was number necessary to companystitute the offence under clause d of s. 5 1 that the public servant must do some thing in companynection with his own duty

precedents.case_name: State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: Public servant must misconduct in discharge of own duty for offence under s.5(1)(d) of Corruption Act

precedents.citation: M. Narayanan Nambiar v. State of Kerala 1

anchor.surface_text: The case of M. Narayanan Nambiar v. State of Kerala 1 was clearly one in which there had been abuse by a Government servant of his. position as a public servant.

precedents.case_name: M. Narayanan Nambiar v. State of Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: Abuse of position as public servant is essential for offence under s.5(1)(d); 'by otherwise' qualifies abuse of position and savours of dishonest act
precedents.cited_holding: The gist of the offence under this clause is that a public officer abusing his position as a public servant obtains for himself or for any other person any valuable thing or pecuniary advantage

precedents.citation: Ram Krishna Another v The State of Delhi 2

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also relied on the analysis of s. 5 1 d companytained in Ram Krishna Another v The State of Delhi 2 , where it was pointed out that the offence created thereby is of four kinds.

precedents.case_name: Ram Krishna & Anr. v. The State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Offence under s.5(1)(d) requires abuse of position as public servant, consistent with other clauses; obtains includes acceptance, solicitation or extortion
precedents.cited_holding: in clauses a , b and c the abuse of position as a public servant is clearly implied. Clause e also carries the same implication. It would, therefore, be reasonable to put on clause d a construction which is consistent with the other clauses
